summary: Move metadata (cover, themes, visibility) into slide-out drawer and hide from default view
problem_statement: Metadata controls (cover image, themes, visibility) are currently exposed in the default Write view, competing for attention with the writing surface. Every visible control adds cognitive load and decision fatigue. Writers need these options available but not present—a slide-out drawer keeps them reachable without cluttering the default view. Blocking modals or persistent panels undermine the attention-protecting promise.
in_scope: Implement slide-out drawer or panel for metadata (cover, themes, visibility)
Hide metadata controls from default Write view
Provide clear affordance to open the panel (e.g. icon, label)
out_of_scope: Visual styling beyond panel layout (P2 accent, breathing space)
requirements: Metadata panel is hidden by default in Write view
Panel opens via non-blocking interaction (slide, overlay, or drawer)
Cover, themes, and visibility controls live inside the panel
Epic DoD: ≤5 visible controls in default view
acceptance_criteria: Metadata controls are not visible in default Write view
Slide-out panel opens and closes without blocking the editor
Cover, themes, and visibility are accessible from the panel
Panel interaction is accessible (keyboard, screen reader)
dependencies: P1-uix-01 (Full-width editor layout) — panel must work with expanded viewport
risks: Users may not discover the panel if affordance is too subtle
Slide-out animation must feel instant (<200ms) to avoid perceived lag
implementation_notes: P1-uix-02 follows P1-uix-01. The full-width layout creates space; this atomic moves controls out of it. Prefer a drawer from the right or a collapsible sidebar. Avoid modals. Reference epic DoD: cognitive load ≤5 visible controls.
